unnormalised: Okay, so you know how we're all trying to be more health-conscious these days? It's not just about hitting the gym or eating more salad, it's also about understanding the *numbers* involved in our healthcare journey. I mean, think about it, from checking your weight to figuring out your dosage of medicines, units of measurement are everywhere! And in India, we have our own unique way of talking about them sometimes.
normalised: Okay, so you know how we're all trying to be more health-conscious these days? It's not just about hitting the gym or eating more salad, it's also about understanding the numbers involved in our healthcare journey. I mean, think about it, from checking your weight to figuring out your dosage of medicines, units of measurement are everywhere! And in India, we have our own unique way of talking about them sometimes.

unnormalised: First off, let's talk weight. You might hear someone say they've lost "2 kgs" after a week of dieting. Everyone knows what kgs (kilograms) are, right? It's the standard way we measure weight in India. But then, your grandma might still be using "seer" or "chatak" for smaller quantities when talking about traditional remedies. Those units are ancient! Though, thankfully, we mostly stick to grams (g) or milligrams (mg) when dealing with medicines.
normalised: First off, let's talk weight. You might hear someone say they've lost two kilograms after a week of dieting. Everyone knows what kilograms are, right? It's the standard way we measure weight in India. But then, your grandma might still be using "seer" or "chatak" for smaller quantities when talking about traditional remedies. Those units are ancient! Though, thankfully, we mostly stick to grams or milligrams when dealing with medicines.

unnormalised: Now, let's get to the fun part – medicines! If Dr. Sharma prescribes you Amoxicillin, it will probably be something like "250 mg" or "500mg" capsules. You'll also encounter terms like "ml" (milliliters) for syrups. Dosage is *super* important, guys, so don’t just go eyeballing it! Always follow the doctor's instructions. Also, ever noticed how IV fluids are often measured in "L" (liters)? Keep an eye on that bottle!

Also, ever noticed how I-V fluids are often measured in liters? Keep an eye on that bottle!

unnormalised: Then there's blood pressure. You go to the clinic, and they tell you, "120/80 mmHg". What does that even mean? The "mmHg" part stands for millimeters of mercury and that’s the unit used to measure the pressure of your blood pushing against the walls of your arteries. It's a bit weird, I know, but that’s the global standard for measuring blood pressure. Understanding the units can actually help ease anxiety around seeing those numbers.

It's a bit weird, I know, but that's the global standard for measuring blood pressure. Understanding the units can actually help ease anxiety around seeing those numbers.

unnormalised: Think about body temperature. During fever season, we’re all running around checking our temperatures. We mostly use degrees Celsius (°C) here in India. A normal temperature is around 37°C but if the doc reports you have "101°F", that's degrees Fahrenheit, which is still used, mostly by doctors and can mean fever, depending on your baseline. Confusing? A bit! But knowing both is helpful.

unnormalised: Another thing to remember is height. Most doctors use cm (centimeters) or m (meters), although older folks will still ask how many "feet and inches" tall you are, and the conversion is always a math problem! Knowing these units helps us track growth, especially in kids. I remember when my nephew went from 2 ft to almost 4 ft in just a couple of years. Time flies!

unnormalised: So, next time you're at the doctor's office, take a moment to think about all the different units of measurement being used. It's not just random numbers and letters; they're the tools that help healthcare professionals keep us healthy! And in a country as diverse as India, it's helpful to know a bit about the traditional and modern units we use. Stay healthy, folks!
